The Ridge is a large open space, located in the heart of Shimla, the capital city of Himachal Pradesh, India. It runs east to west alongside the Mall Road, and joins it at the Scandal Point on the west side. On the east side, The Ridge road leads to Lakkar Bazaar, a wooden crafts market. The Ridge houses a large water reservoir which acts as the main supply of Shimla town. 

One can do horse riding here. Sit here and enjoy the cool and clear environment with Himalayas views. Many hawkers sells eatables that makes the place a bit dirty.  

The Ridge road is also the venue for Summer festival, government functions and local celebrations during New Year's Eve. Prominent landmarks on The Ridge include Christ Church built in the 1850s and a library building built in 1910. There are three statues on The Ridge- that of Mahatma Gandhi, Indira Gandhi and Dr. Y.S. Parmar, the first Chief Minister of Himachal Pradesh.

The ridge has remained unchanged after all these years, however, it is too commercialised and crowded today. The vendors hawking balloons and toys, too many street food vendors etc diminish the overall aura somewhat

The Ridge is the heart of Shimla. If you talk of Shimla, it would be incomplete without mentioning this place. The Ridge road is a large open space and is the hub of all cultural activities of Shimla. It is situated along the Mall Road, which is the famous shopping center of Shimla. Most major places of Shimla like Snowdon, Mall, Jakhoo hill, etc. are connected through the Ridge.

It runs east to west alongside the Mall Road, and joins it at the Scandal Point on the west side. On the east side, The Ridge road leads to Lakkar Bazaar, a wooden crafts market. It's the major landmark and the most easily recognized face of the hill station. When winter sets in and Shimla experiences its first major snowfall of the year, most news papers print photos of the ridge submerged in clumps of fresh snow.

Prominent landmarks on the Ridge are a neo-Gothic Christ church built in 1844 and a library building built in 1910. There are various statues on the ridge like that of Mahatma Gandhi, Indira Gandhi, and Dr. Y.S. Parmar, the first chief minister of Himachal Pradesh.

The ridge of Shimla had the thickest forest of the area at one time. Now the green slopes are covered with firs, pines, Himalayan oak and carmine rhododendron trees.

The Ridge is the most popular attraction of Shimla.   It is a vast pedestrian-only open area ringed by metallic railings.  All around there are impressive buildings, including the Christ Church and the stone-built Town Hall. People can also find neatly tended and attractive parks, and statues of local and national leaders. From the railings, they can have sweeping views in all directions of the dramatic wooded hills, interspersed with picturesquely tiled terraces of houses and in the distance the snow-capped peaks of the high Himalayas.  People throng the place always.  The Ridge comes alive during the times of snowfall, when people in warm clothes can be seen skiing and throwing balls of snow at others. 

As vehicles are not allowed into it, visitors have to climb approach streets, which are somewhat steep but well paved, to reach it.   From the Ridge the famous 108-foot Jakhu Hill Hanuman statue can be seen emerging out of the greenery in the distance. 

It is a good place for the young and the old to hang out or walk around leisurely enjoying a cone of ice cream.   It is one of the most photographed areas of Shimla.

Pleasent and sunny morning it's 8am, I am at The Ridge, Shimla, sipping hot tea sitting on one of the many neatly laid out benches. The place is full of positive energy as the local people carry on with their daily affair. Children nicely groomed and dressed in uniform walking all the way through the mall to their schools on the ridge (no vehicles, not even bicycles in this area) look cheerful with their pink cheeks. Some little grown ups stop by for a cricket match of 2 overs to give themselves a few minutes of break to scale next elevation of walk. No sleepy or dull faces, they look brimming with enthusiasm. Watching people passby, some taking a stroll, some going for their work, seniors chit-chatting and flipping through newspaper, all are relaxed but motivated. A porter finds enough strength to load 2 filled indane gas cylinders on his back but not beg or steal, I have not seen a beggar here yet. While they intend to reach their destination in time, they find time to greet and stop for a minute of conversation if any one known comes across. As the Indian flag flies high at the ridge, the place as cleanly maintained as this, with natural beauty around, cultured and respectful people, this is a true salute to the spirit of flag and statues it hoists. While the beautiful views of the valley from the ridge and shopping across the mall are well known tourist attractions, this experience of just watching the life move on in this beautiful town of Shimla has been amazing and really rejuvenating. As the day passes and sun brightens, people may get to deal with the challenges in their lives, but I am sure they lift themselves up with great spirit every next morning. While we may see very beautiful places in the world, the wonderful people make of beautiful experience and I have just had one today morning. As the 10am siren sounds loud and mall road shop shutters open up, I get up from my bench with by now emptied four tea cups and head back to my hotel to accomplish my tourist sightseeing targets for the day with my family, probably including more touristy, over-crowded ridge in the evening with many hawkers around.

Scrape_Tagline: It's a walk that should not be missed
Scrape_Review_Text: Stretching from Christ Church to Scandal Point, The Ridge is an open space in Shimla's centre.  As you walk along it you will pass many historic buildings and statues.  Among the buildings are the Hawa Ghar (a pavilion with views of The Ridge itself and the surrounding countryside and in front of which there is an imposing statue of Mahatma Gandhi), the Himichal Pradesh State Library and the Gaiety Theatre complex.  There are also a number of interesting statues.  As well as the Mahatma Gandhi statue, there is a bust of Lieutenant-General Daulat Singh (who was killed in a helicopter accident), Dr Y S Parmar (the First Chief Minister of Himachal Pradesh state), Atal Bighari Vapajee (a poet who served three terms as the tenth Prime Minister of India) and Indira Gandhi (who, as well as being Mahatma Gandhi's daughter, also served as India's third and fifth Prime Minister).  On top of all these buildings and statues, The Ridge also commands some magnificent views of the surrounding countryside.  It's a walk that should not be missed.
